channel.title: CNN.com - RSS Channel - App International Edition
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.

image.title: CNN.com - RSS Channel - App International Edition

channel.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 Turner Broadcasting System, Inc. All Rights Reserved.

item.title: Merkel warns Germany is on 'thinnest ice' as Europe realizes social distancing is here to stay
item.description: Germany risks squandering the gains it has made in slowing down the spread of the novel coronavirus if the country opens up too quickly, Chancellor Angela Merkel warned, joining leaders across Europe who have cautioned that any easing of lockdown restrictions would likely be gradual.

item.title: The dangerous morality behind the 'Open It Up' movement
The secret, selfish rule breakers of Covid-19
item.description: Last week, a Washington, DC-based media executive who is used to attending 200 cocktail parties a year decided that he could take talking to his microwave no more.

item.title: Wuhan resident: A second wave is 'absolutely' coming
item.description: CNN's David Culver returns to Wuhan, China the original epicenter of the novel coronavirus. The city's 11 million residents are attempting to return to normal life and business after a 76-day lockdown.

item.title: An innocent man spent 46 years in prison -- and made a plan to kill the man who framed him
Almost half of coronavirus deaths in Europe were in care homes, WHO says
Herd immunity: What it is, and why some think it could end the pandemic
item.description: The concept of herd immunity is a simple one. But achieving it? Not so much.

item.title: New HHS spokesman made racist comments about Chinese people in now-deleted tweets
item.description: The new spokesman for the Department of Health and Human Services in a series of now-deleted tweets made racist and derogatory comments about Chinese people, said Democrats wanted the coronavirus to kill millions of people and accused the media of intentionally creating panic around the pandemic to hurt President Donald Trump.

item.title: Trial for potential Covid-19 vaccine starts
item.description: Scientists in the UK will begin trials of a potential Covid-19 vaccine on humans Thursday, as the government warns it could have to rely on social distancing measures until next year assuming no vaccine or treatment is found before then.

item.title: Wuhan is on a slow path back to normality after 76-day coronavirus lockdown
item.description: The first city in the world to go into lockdown due to the coronavirus is slowly returning to something that might be described as normal, after months of fear and anxiety.

item.title: Seemingly healthy woman's sudden death now first known US coronavirus-related fatality: LA Times
item.description: A seemingly healthy 57-year-old Bay Area woman who "suddenly died" in early February has now become the first known US death related to coronavirus, the Los Angeles Times reported Wednesday.

item.title: 'Welcome to the house of horror': The awful economic data for April is here
The Vegas mayor gave an absolutely wild interview to Anderson Cooper
item.description: On Wednesday afternoon, CNN's Anderson Cooper interviewed independent Las Vegas Mayor Carolyn Goodman. Seems innocent enough, right? Mayor of a major American city appears on cable TV to talk about the challenges of coronavirus and how local, state and federal government can work together to ensure re-opening the economy is safe for citizens. Normal stuff!

item.title: Nevada governor responds to Las Vegas mayor's remarks
item.description: Nevada Gov. Steve Sisolak responds to Las Vegas Mayor Carolyn Goodman's comments to CNN's Anderson Cooper appearing to offer the city as a control group for coronavirus guidelines.

item.title: They won the fight against coronavirus. Here's what life looks like on the other side
item.description: Cookie Villarreal was finally home. She had beaten the novel coronavirus but she couldn't get dressed by herself or even raise her arms to brush her hair.

item.title: Seniors with Covid-19 show unusual symptoms, doctors say
Preliminary antibody testing in New York suggests much wider spread of coronavirus
item.description: A preliminary study of 3,000 New Yorkers found that 13.9% tested positive for coronavirus antibodies, Gov. Andrew Cuomo said Thursday.

item.title: Air pollution in northern India has hit a 20-year low, NASA report says
item.description: For years, northern India -- especially the capital New Delhi -- has been battling air pollution with levels hitting the hazardous mark during the winter season.

item.title: Elizabeth Warren says her oldest brother died of coronavirus
item.description: Sen. Elizabeth Warren announced Thursday her oldest brother Donald Reed Herring died after testing positive for coronavirus.

item.title: Trump's standing in battleground states may be slipping
item.description: President Donald Trump's path to reelection was always going to hinge on his performance in a handful of swing states. That path looks more perilous for the President in a series of recent high-quality polls.

item.title: Asian wet markets get bad press. See what they're really like
item.description: A common sight across Asia, wet markets traditionally sell fresh produce and live animals. Some include wild animal products linked to diseases. CNN's Kristie Lu Stout explains the diverse array of wet markets in Asia.

item.title: Footage shows thief using sledgehammer to steal Van Gogh painting
item.description: Video footage shows how a sledgehammer-wielding thief broke into a museum in the Netherlands and walked off with a painting by Vincent van Gogh.

item.title: Amazon revealed to be behind mystery $310,000 donation to bookshops
item.description: Amazon has been revealed to be behind a mystery £250,000 ($310,000) donation to a charity that supports independent booksellers in the UK and Ireland.

item.title: New photos of Prince Louis painting rainbows released to mark his second birthday
item.description: The Royal Family has released photographs of Prince Louis painting rainbows to mark his second birthday.

item.title: Construction begins on world's biggest football stadium
item.description: Chinese champions Guangzhou Evergrande are building the world's biggest football stadium for $1.7B. It will seat 100,000 and is designed in a lotus flower shape.

item.title: How gyms got Trump to include them in Phase One of his reopening plan
item.description: When President Donald Trump revealed his guidelines for "opening up America again" last week, among the bolded names of businesses and institutions that could reopen were restaurants, movie theaters and places of worship -- so long as they adhered to strict social distancing protocols. Tucked near the bottom of the list, right above a warning that bars should stay closed, was a curious inclusion: gyms.

item.title: Simona Halep's lockdown life: military on the streets, slower pace at home
item.description: While soldiers are patrolling the streets of Bucharest, Wimbledon champion Simona Halep has been adjusting to a new, different pace of life.

item.title: A 100-year-old WWII veteran died of Covid-19. His twin brother died 100 years earlier in the flu pandemic
item.description: A 100-year-old World War II veteran who died from Covid-19 lost a twin brother to the 1918 pandemic a century earlier, his grandson said.

item.title: How coronavirus has changed Ramadan for Muslims this year
item.description: Thursday marks the start of the holy month of Ramadan for many Muslims.

item.title: The first ever YouTube video was uploaded 15 years ago today. Here it is
item.description: Time to hit rewind.

item.title: Coronavirus test can produce false negatives, company says
item.description: Abbott Laboratories, the maker of a rapid coronavirus test widely used across the United States and distributed by the federal government, has warned that its device can produce false negatives if a special solution is used to move or store patients' samples. CNN's Drew Griffin has the details.

item.title: Now you can remote control people in the Faroe Islands
item.description: Amid the worldwide Covid-19 outbreak, tourist attractions around the world have closed their doors and moved things online, providing virtual reality experiences and museum tours.

item.title: Man is trying to visit every nation in the world without flying. But he's stuck in Hong Kong due to Covid-19
item.description: Torbjørn "Thor" Pedersen is on a mission to visit every country in the world in a single journey, without taking a single flight.

item.title: With no people, safari owners fear a rise in poaching
item.description: Safari operators say a lack of business has a secondary sinister affect on the animals in the African wilderness areas.

item.title: 12 Frank Lloyd Wright buildings are now hosting virtual tours
item.description: Ever wanted to go inside Frank Lloyd Wright's iconic Fallingwater? Now's your chance (even if the US is on lockdown) thanks to a new series of digital tours.

item.title: Ford engineers are working on electric Mustang SUVs in their own garages
item.description: When Aleyna Kapur started working from home due to the coronavirus pandemic, she had to take a few things from the office: her laptop, some cables and a Ford Mustang Mach-E electric SUV.

item.title: These ancient images of the Buddha are more timely than you think
item.description: What was the Buddha's great wisdom, and how do the artworks of the Buddhist tradition convey it to us today?

item.title: 8 big cats have tested positive for coronavirus at the Bronx Zoo
item.description: Seven more big cats have coronavirus at the Bronx Zoo, in addition to a tiger that tested positive earlier this month, the Wildlife Conservation Society announced.

item.title: Massive 'ice shoves' threaten lakeside homes
item.description: See 30-foot-tall ice walls, also known as "ice shoves," move into lakeside homes in Minnesota. Warm weather has caused the ice on the lake to thaw causing ice waves to slowly crash into homes on the shore.

item.title: Growing up in a high altitude area may lower chronic disease risk, study finds
item.description: Living near the Tibetan Plateau, often referred to as "The Roof of the World," may have more benefits than scenic pleasure.

item.title: Tom Selleck gives a rare interview on fame, family and why he quit 'Magnum P.I.'
item.description: Tom Selleck was one of the hottest stars of the 1980s when he suddenly quit his hit show, "Magnum P.I."

item.title: Anna Wintour calls on the fashion industry to 'rethink our values'
item.description: In a video call with supermodel Naomi Campbell, the Vogue editor-in-chief says Covid-19 means fashion will never be the same again.

item.title: After dinosaurs went extinct, some birds shrank but kept their big brains
item.description: Being called a "bird brain" may be closer to a compliment than an insult.

item.title: Stanley Tucci shows off quarantine bartending skills
item.description: Actor Staley Tucci takes to Instagram to show off his bartending skills with a video of himself teaching followers how to make the perfect Negroni.

item.title: Almost half of deaths in Europe were in care homes: WHO
Nearly all patients put on ventilators in New York's largest health system died, study finds
item.description: Nearly all coronavirus patients who needed ventilators in New York's largest health system to help them breathe died, a study found.

item.title: Chaos overtakes Trump admin's virus response
item.description: Alarming new signs are emerging that the Trump administration is shunting science aside in the battle against coronavirus.

item.title: Task force members sent Birx to convince Trump to denounce Georgia reopening decision, source says
item.description: Members of the coronavirus task force had to convince President Donald Trump to change his view on Georgia's Republican governor's decision to reopen businesses in his state later this week, a source close to the task force told CNN.

item.title: An innocent man spent 46 years in prison. He planned to kill the guy who framed him
The hypocrisy of the 'Open it Up' movement
item.description: A healthcare worker in green scrubs stands in the middle of an intersection, staring down a traffic jam of screaming protesters demanding a return to their livelihoods and liberties.
